content.webTitle: Jamaal Lascelles tells Newcastle fans: drop the protests and get behind us

fields.headline: Jamaal Lascelles tells Newcastle fans: drop the protests and get behind us
fields.bodyText: Jamaal Lascelles has advised Newcastle United fans to abandon plans to boycott matches in protest at Mike Ashley’s stewardship of the club. Rafael Benítez’s captain believes that a restoration of off-field harmony is essential to the team’s chances of Premier League survival and told supporters that Newcastle’s owner is a “nice guy”, before urging them to “stop the negativity” and eliminate “bad energy”. Lascelles met Ashley for the first time last month, when the businessman treated the squad to an Italian meal. “I know fingers are being pointed at him,” he said. “But the meal was really positive. He’s a nice guy. I like him. If everyone in Newcastle stopped the negativity and tried to form a unity it would help. It’s important that everyone’s together, especially when we’re down at the bottom of the table.” Benítez’s side are without a win and face Watford at home on Saturday against a backdrop of discontent which has seen leading fans’ groups urge a boycott of the televised game against Wolves at St James’ Park in December. “When there are problems off the pitch it does affect you as players,” said Lascelles, who has just signed a lucrative six-year contract extension. “It would help if everyone came together and put all that bad energy into positive energy, helping us get three points. If you’re always hearing negativity and you’ve got the fans against Mike it just creates a big negative mess. It doesn’t help. It affects the chemistry in the changing room.” Supporters are furious about Ashley’s persistent refusal to back Benítez in the transfer market and Lascelles accepts there is a clear consensus that the squad needs reinforcing. “I understand the fans’ frustration,” he said. “But when 52,000 Geordies get behind us, it gives such an uplift. My message is stick with us. The fans are entitled to sing about Mike Ashley but it does impact on us.” Lascelles appears to have been won over by the owner in that Northumberland restaurant. “We had a couple of drinks and he just seemed like a normal person,” the 24-year-old said. “We talked about normal stuff, men to men. “The club feels more united now. Our dressing room’s strong – it’s not like when I first came here and there was a clique of French lads, a group of Spanish lads, the English lads and another group in the corner – but we’d be a much better club without all the negativity and bad energy.” The problem is Benítez’s understandable unwillingness to extend a contract with six months remaining. Lascelles opted to swerve the topic. “I didn’t know there was uncertainty about him not being here. Us players aren’t aware of that. I don’t really sense that. But, as long as he’s here, this club will keep going up and up.” Lascelles is softly spoken but team-mates testify he can turn feisty in training. “It’s a man’s sport,” he said. “Even in female sports you’ll get upsets, adrenaline’s flying, one bad tackle or bad decision can get somebody saying something. Someone might have had a bad day at home, someone might be having family problems. “At training, especially when you’re not winning games, things can spark, but it’s completely normal. It doesn’t mean you don’t like this person, it doesn’t mean it’s anything personal. You might push each other, you might punch each other, you might lash out. I’m not saying it’s a good thing, but it happens. “Ask Alan Shearer, ask any ex-Newcastle players, they’ll have seen it all and been involved in it. It’s really not that big a deal.” Such incidents at least show Lascelles cares. “I love Newcastle to bits,” he said. “If we were relegated I’d want to be part of the team that gets promoted. But we’re not going to get relegated. It’s not happening.”
